gridDisplay.subtitle: Ix Chel- "Lady Rainbow" / "She of the Rainbow"
gridDisplay.title: Maya - Ixchel

subtitle: Ix Chel- "Lady Rainbow" / "She of the Rainbow"

listDisplay.expandedContent:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
                divinity. As goddess of the moon, childbirth, medicine, and weaving, she presides over the cycles
                of life, fertility, and death. Appearing both as a beautiful young woman and as a fearsome crone,
                she represents the transformative power of the feminine across all stages of life. Her sacred shrine
                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.
listDisplay.secondary:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
...

sections.title: Description
sections.content:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
                divinity. As goddess of the moon, childbirth, medicine, and weaving, she presides over the cycles
                of life, fertility, and death. Appearing both as a beautiful young woman and as a fearsome crone,
                she represents the transformative power of the feminine across all stages of life. Her sacred shrine
                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.

description:

                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.
summary:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
                divinity. As goddess of the moon, childbirth, medicine, and weaving, she presides over the cycles

                she represents the transformative power of the feminine across all stages of life. Her sacred shrine
                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.

dualGoddess.description: Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine divinity, appearing in two distinct aspects that represent the transformative cycles of feminine power.

youngMoon.description: In her youthful aspect, Ixchel appears as a beautiful young woman associated with sexuality, fertility, and the waxing moon. She is depicted with long, flowing hair, bare breasts, and often holding a rabbit - the creature the Maya saw in the patterns of the moon's surface.
youngMoon.associations: This aspect connects her to romantic love, new life, and the creative power of feminine sexuality.

agedCrone.aspect: Goddess O - Chak Chel the Crone
agedCrone.description: As Chak Chel ('Red/Great Rainbow'), Ixchel appears as a powerful aged woman with jaguar attributes - clawed hands, a skirt decorated with crossbones, and a serpent headdress. This aspect represents the destructive face of feminine power, associated with floods, storms, and death.
agedCrone.waterJar: She is depicted pouring water from an overturned jar, bringing either life-giving rain or devastating floods.
agedCrone.healingPower: Far from being feared, Chak Chel was honored as a powerful healing deity. Her association with medicine, midwifery, and divination made her one of the most important goddesses in Maya daily life.

mythologyNarratives.rabbitInTheMoon: The Maya, like many Mesoamerican peoples, saw a rabbit rather than a face in the moon's markings. According to myth, Ixchel keeps a rabbit as her companion, and this lunar rabbit is associated with fertility, writing (rabbit-scribes appear in Maya art), and the cycles of the moon.

cozumelSanctuary.description: The island of Cozumel ('Island of Swallows') off the coast of Yucatan was Ixchel's most sacred site. The Spanish called it Isla de Mujeres ('Island of Women') because of the goddess figurines found there.
cozumelSanctuary.pilgrimage: Women from across the Maya world made pilgrimages to Cozumel to seek Ixchel's blessing, particularly for fertility and safe childbirth.
cozumelSanctuary.oracle: The temple of San Gervasio was the center of her cult, where priestesses served as oracles, delivering Ixchel's messages to pilgrims. The goddess was said to speak through these women, offering guidance on matters of health, fertility, and the future.

forms.cozumelPilgrimage: Women traveled from across Yucatan to seek the goddess
forms.fertilityOfferings: Jade, textiles, and other precious items
forms.midwifeCeremonies: Rituals invoking Ixchel's aid in childbirth

cosmology.lunarGoddess: Personification of the moon and its cycles - the moon's phases were intimately connected to women's fertility cycles

threeRealms.celestial: As Moon Goddess, Ixchel traverses the night sky
threeRealms.earthly: As patron of weaving, medicine, and childbirth, she is active in human daily life
threeRealms.underworld: Her crone aspect is associated with floods and destructive waters connecting to the underworld

sacredWeaving.cosmicSymbol: The loom itself was seen as a cosmic symbol - the warp and weft representing the intersection of cosmic forces, the creation of order from chaos.
sacredWeaving.divineArt: Weaving was a sacred art among the Maya, and Ixchel was its divine inventor and patron. She taught women to spin thread and weave cloth, transforming raw cotton into elaborate textiles.

namesAndMeanings.youngAspect: The Moon Goddess / Goddess I - beautiful young woman
namesAndMeanings.oldAspect: Chak Chel / Goddess O - powerful aged crone

attributesAndDomains.sacredSite: Cozumel Island (Isla de las Mujeres - 'Island of Women')

artOfWeaving.sacredPractice: Maya textiles were works of art encoding social status, regional identity, and sacred symbolism. Women weavers saw themselves as participating in divine creativity, their work echoing Ixchel's original act of bringing forth cloth from thread.
artOfWeaving.livingTradition: The backstrap loom remains central to Maya women's cultural identity today, an unbroken tradition stretching back millennia to Ixchel's original teachings.

sacredConnections.spindleAndThread: Symbols of fate and life's continuity
sacredConnections.theLoom: Cosmic symbol representing the intersection of forces
sacredConnections.spiderAssociations: The spider as divine weaver, connected to Ixchel

iconography.youngForm: Beautiful woman with long hair, bare breasts, holding or accompanied by a rabbit; lunar crescent associations
iconography.agedForm: Powerful crone with jaguar claws, serpent headdress, skirt with crossbones, pouring water from an overturned jar
iconography.rainbow: Her name-symbol, connecting earth and sky, appearing after rain - sign of her presence
iconography.waterJar: Vessel of life-giving rain or destructive floods, representing her dual nature

extendedContent.modernSignificance: Ixchel remains one of the most beloved deities of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica, particularly among women. In contemporary Maya communities, traditional midwives and healers continue practices that honor Ixchel. Maya women weavers today often acknowledge Ixchel as the patron of their art, maintaining a living connection to ancient traditions.

periods.description: Fully developed as moon, fertility, and medicine goddess
Pilgrimage site at Cozumel devoted to her

calendarAssociations.lunar: Sacred 260-day calendar tied to human gestation (9 lunar months)
calendarAssociations.mayanMonth: Ix - month associated with feminine energy
calendarAssociations.significance: Moon cycles regulated women's fertility and healing

preColumbian.name: Dresden Codex
preColumbian.content: Ixchel / Ixik associations with weaving and moon phases

preColumbian.name: Popol Vuh
preColumbian.content: Moon goddess mythology and female creation role

colonialSpanish.name: RelaciÃ³n de las Cosas de YucatÃ¡n
colonialSpanish.author: Fray Diego de Landa
colonialSpanish.content: Ixchel pilgrimage at Cozumel and fertility rituals

colonialSpanish.name: Reports of Spanish conquistadors
colonialSpanish.content: Cozumel shrine and continuous pilgrimage tradition

primary.name: Cozumel Island Shrine
primary.description: Sacred pilgrimage destination with Ixchel temple
primary.pilgrimage: Women traveled from throughout Maya world for healing and fertility rites
primary.colonial: Spanish conquistadors encountered active pilgrimage when they arrived 1519

secondary.name: Tikal
secondary.description: Feminine deity representations in temple inscriptions

secondary.name: Caracol
secondary.description: Moon goddess associations with astronomical observations

weavingTradition.significance: Weaving as sacred art - Ixchel taught humans this craft
weavingTradition.backstrap_loom: Still used by Maya women, tool blessed with Ixchel prayers
weavingTradition.textiles: Pattern designs contain sacred cosmological meanings

feminineDivinity.aspects: Moon goddess, weaving patroness, medicine woman, childbirth guardian
feminineDivinity.duality: Young beautiful woman and fearsome crone (creative and destructive)
feminineDivinity.consort: Paired with Itzamna as cosmic creative couple

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
